conclusion: Identify suitcase mass, pull force, and angle θ; find μ and θ.
Suitcase moves uniformly, net force is zero (Newton's first law).
Identify forces: Gravity, Normal force, Friction force, Pull force.
Free-body diagram: Gravity down, Normal up, Friction horizontal, Pull at angle θ.
Sum of forces in horizontal and vertical directions is zero.
Break pull force into components: F_x = F * cos(θ), F_y = F * sin(θ).
Horizontal equilibrium: F * cos(θ) - f = 0, so f = F * cos(θ).
Vertical equilibrium: N + F * sin(θ) - G = 0, so N = G - F * sin(θ).
Friction force f is proportional to normal force N: f = μ * N.
Set f = F * cos(θ) equal to μ * N: F * cos(θ) = μ * (G - F * sin(θ)).
Weight G = m * g, with m = 15 kg and g = 10 m/s², so G = 150 N.
Equation: F * cos(θ) = μ * (150 - F * sin(θ)).
Divide by F: cos(θ) = μ * (150/F - sin(θ)).
Given F = 90 N, plug in values: μ = -cos(θ) / (sin(θ) - 5/3).
Since sin(θ) < 5/3, sin(θ) - 5/3 is negative, but μ must be positive.
